camel.sink.path.apiName.name: camel.sink.path.apiName
camel.sink.path.apiName.description: What kind of operation to perform One of: [THREADS] [MESSAGES] [ATTACHMENTS] [LABELS] [HISTORY] [DRAFTS] [USERS]

camel.sink.path.methodName.name: camel.sink.path.methodName
camel.sink.path.methodName.description: What sub operation to use for the selected operation One of: [attachments] [create] [delete] [get] [getProfile] [gmailImport] [insert] [list] [modify] [patch] [send] [stop] [trash] [untrash] [update] [watch]

camel.sink.endpoint.applicationName.name: camel.sink.endpoint.applicationName
camel.sink.endpoint.applicationName.description: Google mail application name. Example would be camel-google-mail/1.0

camel.sink.endpoint.clientId.name: camel.sink.endpoint.clientId
camel.sink.endpoint.clientId.description: Client ID of the mail application

camel.sink.endpoint.inBody.name: camel.sink.endpoint.inBody
camel.sink.endpoint.inBody.description: Sets the name of a parameter to be passed in the exchange In Body

camel.sink.endpoint.lazyStartProducer.name: camel.sink.endpoint.lazyStartProducer
camel.sink.endpoint.lazyStartProducer.description: Whether the producer should be started lazy (on the first message). By starting lazy you can use this to allow CamelContext and routes to startup in situations where a producer may otherwise fail during starting and cause the route to fail being started. By deferring this startup to be lazy then the startup failure can be handled during routing messages via Camel's routing error handlers. Beware that when the first message is processed then creating and starting the producer may take a little time and prolong the total processing time of the processing.

camel.sink.endpoint.basicPropertyBinding.name: camel.sink.endpoint.basicPropertyBinding
camel.sink.endpoint.basicPropertyBinding.description: Whether the endpoint should use basic property binding (Camel 2.x) or the newer property binding with additional capabilities

camel.sink.endpoint.synchronous.name: camel.sink.endpoint.synchronous
camel.sink.endpoint.synchronous.description: Sets whether synchronous processing should be strictly used, or Camel is allowed to use asynchronous processing (if supported).

camel.sink.endpoint.accessToken.name: camel.sink.endpoint.accessToken
camel.sink.endpoint.accessToken.description: OAuth 2 access token. This typically expires after an hour so refreshToken is recommended for long term usage.

camel.sink.endpoint.clientSecret.name: camel.sink.endpoint.clientSecret
camel.sink.endpoint.clientSecret.description: Client secret of the mail application

camel.sink.endpoint.refreshToken.name: camel.sink.endpoint.refreshToken
camel.sink.endpoint.refreshToken.description: OAuth 2 refresh token. Using this, the Google Calendar component can obtain a new accessToken whenever the current one expires - a necessity if the application is long-lived.

camel.component.google-mail.applicationN.name: camel.component.google-mail.applicationName
camel.component.google-mail.applicationN.description: Google mail application name. Example would be camel-google-mail/1.0

camel.component.google-mail.clientId.name: camel.component.google-mail.clientId
camel.component.google-mail.clientId.description: Client ID of the mail application

camel.component.google-mail.lazyStartPro.name: camel.component.google-mail.lazyStartProducer
camel.component.google-mail.lazyStartPro.description: Whether the producer should be started lazy (on the first message). By starting lazy you can use this to allow CamelContext and routes to startup in situations where a producer may otherwise fail during starting and cause the route to fail being started. By deferring this startup to be lazy then the startup failure can be handled during routing messages via Camel's routing error handlers. Beware that when the first message is processed then creating and starting the producer may take a little time and prolong the total processing time of the processing.

camel.component.google-mail.basicPropert.name: camel.component.google-mail.basicPropertyBinding
camel.component.google-mail.basicPropert.description: Whether the component should use basic property binding (Camel 2.x) or the newer property binding with additional capabilities

camel.component.google-mail.clientFactor.name: camel.component.google-mail.clientFactory
camel.component.google-mail.clientFactor.description: To use the GoogleCalendarClientFactory as factory for creating the client. Will by default use BatchGoogleMailClientFactory

camel.component.google-mail.accessToken.name: camel.component.google-mail.accessToken
camel.component.google-mail.accessToken.description: OAuth 2 access token. This typically expires after an hour so refreshToken is recommended for long term usage.

camel.component.google-mail.clientSecret.name: camel.component.google-mail.clientSecret
camel.component.google-mail.clientSecret.description: Client secret of the mail application

camel.component.google-mail.refreshToken.name: camel.component.google-mail.refreshToken
camel.component.google-mail.refreshToken.description: OAuth 2 refresh token. Using this, the Google Calendar component can obtain a new accessToken whenever the current one expires - a necessity if the application is long-lived.
